M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a Probate and Family Court may modify a custody judgment upon a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and where modification is **in the best interests of the child**.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION OF CUSTODY ORDER (M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20)

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has **continuing jurisdiction** under **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28** and **M.G.L. c. 215, § 6** to modify custody and parenting orders where a **material and substantial change in circumstances** has occurred since entry of the prior judgment, and such modification would serve the **best interests of the children**.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a material change may be found where communication between parents has broken down to the detriment of the children, or one parent’s behavior undermines the coparenting relationship.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case concerns the standard for removal of children from the Commonwealth when parents share joint legal and physical custody, focusing on a best-interests analysis and the practical impact of relocation on joint custody. It does not discuss modification based on a material change in circumstances, nor breakdown in parental communication or undermining of the coparenting relationship as a basis for such a finding. The opinion’s treatment of joint custody emphasizes the need for cooperation but does not hold that breakdowns in communication constitute a material change.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “Although the General Laws state that there is no presumption ‘either in favor or against shared . . . custody at the time of trial on the merits,’ G. L. c. 208, § 31, such an arrangement is generally appropriate only if the parties demonstrate an ability and desire to cooperate amicably and communicate with one another to raise the children. … Shared physical custody in particular carries with it substantial obligation for cooperation between the parents.”

Hale v. Hale, 394 Mass. 746 (1985).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a material change may be found where communication between parents has broken down to the detriment of the children, or one parent’s behavior undermines the coparenting relationship.
Hale v. Hale, 394 Mass. 746 (1985).support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a criminal case involving police officers’ criminal liability and grand jury/proximate cause issues; it does not concern family law, custody, or modification of parenting orders. There is no discussion of material change in circumstances, breakdown of parental communication, or undermining of a coparenting relationship. Accordingly, this case cannot be used as authority for the stated proposition about Massachusetts custody modification standards.
Hale v. Hale, 394 Mass. 746 (1985).relevant_excerpt:
In conclusion, we reject each of the arguments advanced by the defendants to set aside their convictions. Finding no error, we therefore affirm the judgments of conviction entered on the jury verdicts in the Superior Court.

[The opinion addresses grand jury prejudice, causation instructions, closing argument, manslaughter instructions, voir dire of witnesses, intervening cause, and sufficiency of the evidence in a homicide prosecution, not family law or custody issues.]

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a material change may be found where communication between parents has broken down to the detriment of the children, or one parent’s behavior undermines the coparenting relationship.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody and visitation standards and emphasizes that severe parental antagonism and inability to cooperate make joint custody inappropriate, but it does so in the context of an initial divorce/custody judgment—not a modification based on a “material change in circumstances.” The case does not frame the parents’ breakdown in communication or coparenting as a ‘material change’ justifying modification of an existing order, nor does it articulate any consistent Massachusetts rule on that point. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition about what constitutes a material change in circumstances.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’ … The judge concluded that ‘joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.’ … [B]ecause the parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing… an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The paramount consideration in all custody determinations is the **best interests of the children**.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the origin and role of the “best interests of the child” standard in custody matters and explicitly reaffirms it as the controlling, paramount inquiry in custody determinations. The court cites prior precedent such as Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas for the proposition that the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, and applies that standard in resolving the custody dispute here.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002)…; Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); Surrender of Minor Children, 344 Mass. 230, 234 (1962)… (‘‘most fundamental [principle] is that the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’’).”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: The paramount consideration in all custody determinations is the **best interests of the children**.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the standard for custody determinations and expressly states that the governing principle is the welfare of the child, described as the “dominating rule.” The court reaffirms prior cases holding that, in custody matters, the happiness and welfare of the child are the controlling consideration, thereby directly supporting the proposition that the best interests of the children are paramount in custody decisions.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ We repeated that same language in Jenkins v. Jenkins, 304 Mass. 248, 250 (1939), and added: ‘…the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: The breakdown of communication and the persistent disparagement by a parent of the other parent to the children constitutes a material change in circumstances.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: This opinion is about statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and relocation/removal of a nonmarital child before paternity is established. It does not address post-judgment modification standards, material change in circumstances, or issues such as breakdown of communication or parental disparagement. Nothing in the reasoning or holding treats those kinds of conduct as a material change, so the case does not support the claimed proposition.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: "Once it was established that the mother had relocated prior to an adjudication of paternity, the judge had no grounds to examine the reasons for or sincerity of the mother’s move. After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate."

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: A modification from shared legal custody to sole legal custody is appropriate when joint decision-making is no longer feasible due to lack of cooperation or communication.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion involves allocation of physical custody and designation of joint legal custody to both parents; it does not address a modification from shared legal custody to sole legal custody. The court’s analysis focuses on best interests in awarding primary physical custody and on one parent’s efforts to undermine the other’s relationship, but it never discusses changing legal custody from joint to sole based on lack of cooperation or communication. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific legal proposition stated.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “She dissolved the parties’ RDP, declared that the parties were legal parents of both children, and granted sole legal and physical custody of Mia to Hunter (which Rose does not challenge) and joint legal custody of Jill with primary physical custody to Hunter. The judge set a parenting schedule of visitation between Rose and Jill.”

Miller v. Todd, 2017 Mass. App. Unpub. L.raw_text: Miller v. Todd, 2017 Mass. App. Unpub. LEXIS 734
Miller v. Todd, 2017 Mass. App. Unpub. L.proposition: A modification from shared legal custody to sole legal custody is appropriate when joint decision-making is no longer feasible due to lack of cooperation or communication.

Ireland v. Ireland, 433 Mass. 479 (2001).proposition: The Court also has authority to clarify parenting schedule terms and conditions to promote the children’s welfare.
Ireland v. Ireland, 433 Mass. 479 (2001).support_reasoning: This opinion is a corporate and employment law case (NetCentric stock repurchase, fiduciary duty, implied covenant, and interference with contractual relations), not a family law or custody/parenting matter. It does not discuss parenting schedules, child custody, or the court’s authority to clarify parenting terms to promote children’s welfare. Therefore, it cannot support the cited proposition about parenting schedule clarification.
Ireland v. Ireland, 433 Mass. 479 (2001).relevant_excerpt:
We affirm the Superior Court’s order allowing the defendants’ motion for summary judgment on the plaintiff’s claims and the defendants’ counterclaim.

So ordered.

[Opinion throughout discusses incorporation in Delaware, fiduciary duties among shareholders, implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing in employment/stock agreements, and intentional interference with contractual relations; it contains no discussion of parenting, custody, or children’s welfare.]

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Court also has authority to clarify parenting schedule terms and conditions to promote the children’s welfare.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on awarding custody and authorizing removal of the children to Greece, along with setting out a visitation schedule. It does not discuss the court’s authority to later clarify parenting schedule terms and conditions, nor does it frame any modification or clarification of the parenting schedule as an exercise of such authority. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about clarifying parenting schedule terms to promote the children’s welfare.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: He further allowed her to remove the children to the Republic of Greece. He gave the husband the right to take the children for six weeks each summer, for one week at Christmas time, and for one week each spring, with the cost of transportation to be shared equally.

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The Court also has authority to clarify parenting schedule terms and conditions to promote the children’s welfare.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly recognizes that in custody and visitation matters the judge’s authority is driven by the child’s best interests, and that this authority includes imposing conditions, restrictions, and even suspension of visitation when necessary for the child’s welfare. While the case focuses on suspending contact rather than fine-tuning a detailed schedule, its reasoning squarely affirms the court’s power to shape and adjust parenting time terms to protect and promote the child’s well-being.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “[T]he strong expression of public policy by our Legislature that a child’s welfare must be the paramount concern when a judge determines custody… means that a judge is authorized not only to order sole legal and physical custody with one parent when it serves the best interests of the child…but also that a judge is authorized to impose conditions and restrictions on and to suspend any visitation by the other parent when it is determined that visitation would not be in the best interests of the child.”
